A copper bangle, part of a set of four. This one is heavy, and undecorated, with a break in the loop. Alldridge s notes say the collection originally came from Upper Guara ; the Guara is a small river running from southern Guinea into Sierra Leone.

A copper bangle, part of a set of four. This one is made from twisted loop of penannular copper. Alldridge s notes say the collection originally came from Upper Guara ; the Guara is a small river running from southern Guinea into Sierra Leone.

A copper and iron bangle, part of a set of four. This one is made from twisted copper and iron, forming a penannular loop. Alldridge s notes say the collection originally came from Upper Guara ; the Guara is a small river running from southern Guinea into Sierra Leone.

A brass bangle, part of a set of four. This one is made from a plain brass penannular loop. Alldridge s notes say the collection originally came from Upper Guara ; the Guara is a small river running from southern Guinea into Sierra Leone.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Body adornment, jewellery; Religious/ritual equipment, charms
CulturalObject.Description: A leather necklace consisting of two thin straps, fastened with loop and leather button. A small oblong charm is attached; such charms generally contain small scripts from the Q uran.
One of four sticks made from bamboo cane. Alldridge noted that these were for making beads.
One of four sticks made from bamboo cane. Alldridge noted that these were for making beads.
One of four sticks made from bamboo cane. Alldridge noted that these were for making beads.
One of four sticks made from bamboo cane. Alldridge noted that these were for making beads.
A bunch of black vine twigs from Vassa Country. Alldridge s notes state that they were used by the Mende for making beads in the late 19th century.
A bunch of Wild Vine roots and stems from Vassa Country. Alldridge s notes state that they were used by the Mende for making beads in the late 19th century.
A container, or box, made out of a hollowed and dried gourd fruit. It has a deep cane rim sewn on to the mouth of the gourd, and a push-in lid.

A woven waist belt, made from eight thin ropes of plated cane fastened with a plaited cotton loop and button at the end. This type of belt was described as a Moiya by Alldridge in 1894. It was said to have been worn by Mandingo boys at Falaba.
Two hide snuff-boxes, penannular in shape, each with a knobbed and plaited round leather strap for suspension.
A wooden draughts board, with 36 figural counters. The board is oblong, with a fan shaped handle. Squares are divided by incised lines and dyed to create a chequerboard effect.

This is a saraka iron chain whip, imbued with magic. Saraka comes from the Arabic word for sacrifice , but was used more generally to refer to objects ritually imbued with spiritual power. The whip has nine iron links, attached to a wooden handle that is studded with iron nails and has an iron loop at the top.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Body adornment, jewellery; Religious/ritual equipment, charms
CulturalObject.Description: A leather bracelet, the catalogue description notes it was worn as a charm . It is made from brown leather and fastens with a loop and leather button. It is decorated with straight and wavy lines. Alldridge stated is was collected from Konno Dugu , which is likely to have been Koinadugu.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Body adornment, jewellery; Religious/ritual equipment, charms
CulturalObject.Description: A plaited leather rope necklace with a pendant made from an oblong piece of ivory scored with four traverse lines, and encased in leather. The necklace is fastened with a loop and triangular leather button.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Bone, ivory, tooth

CulturalObject.Description: A leather charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It consists of a pendant connected to six loops of plaited leather strands affixed to a cloth covered leather button. The pendant is made from horn, part of which is encased in crocodile skin. Alldridge s notes state that the sebbeh was worn by a Mende Chief.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Bone, ivory, tooth

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Body adornment, jewellery; Musical instruments; Religious/ritual equipment, charms
CulturalObject.Description: A bunjue is a musical instrument worn around the waists of dancing girls, or Sampa , initiated into the Sande (Mende) or Bundu (Temne) society. The remaining elements of the costume include a raffia skirt, string vest, and crested cap. This example has 31 bunches of brown nut rattles attached by cane pendants to a plaited fibre belt. Alldridge mentions Bunjue in The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page 244 and Figure. 67.

A leather charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh, the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It consists of a flat oblong pendant, encased in leather on one side, and alligator skin on the other. It has plaited leather edges, attached to four leather plaited loops. Alldridge noted that it was collected from Kaiema, a Kono town. Kaiema was destroyed by the Sofas (In T.J. Alldridge, The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page 278-9).

A leather charm/amulet, or sebe/sebbeh: the Mende and Temne name for charm/amulet. It consists of a square leather pad, with two loops and three leather beads attached to the top, and a tooth mounted in leather. These are suspended on a plaited leather chord with a plaited knob at each end.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Bone, ivory, tooth

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Religious/ritual equipment, charms; Body adornment, jewellery
CulturalObject.Description: These beads are described as medicine beads by Alldridge, worn as a charm by girls initiated into the Bundu or Sande society. The beads are made from a hollow grass-like stem.

A stone figure, known as a nomoli in Mende. The age of figures like this one is relatively unknown, however there is evidence to suggest that they predate Portuguese encounters with the coastal areas of Sierra Leone in the 15th and 16th century. They are thought to have originally represented chiefs or group leaders. More recently, however, such figures have been re-discovered and dug out of the ground, used as rice gods to encourage high yields. Many believe them to be naturally formed, rather than carved.

A Mori leatherwork whip. It has a finely plaited leather whip ending in a triple plait with lashes. The handle is bound with finely plaited leather and a creased skin centre. It has a leather plaited button on the loop at the junction of the whip and the handle. Mori or Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone. See Alldridge s The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page195, for more information.

A Mori leatherwork whip. This example is plaited with a double end of 14 lashes. The handle is bound with very finely plaited leather, except the centre, where it is plain. It has a leather plaited button on the loop at the junction of the whip and the handle. The handle ends in 13 leather strings, each ending in a leather button. Mori or Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone.

An ivory horn with a rope handle. It has raised carved decoration near the mouth piece and incised circular patterns down the body, forming a figure resembling a crocodile. Horns of this kind were often called war horns but a chiefs horn is a more accurate description as they were most commonly played by a hornblower who attended the chief.

A lidded, basin shaped, box, made out of an elephant pad. It has a tight fitting lid, with a loop handle. The original notes compiled by Alldridge say it comes from Sehgu Country, Sierra Leone , though this may relate to Segu town in Mali.
A greyware cooking pot. It is grey in colour with a round base, shoulder and prominent rim. Alldridge notes this type of pot was generally made by Mende women and used for cooking.

This is a wooden palette with a carved bird head handle, used for mixing hojo , a cosmetic or medicine of white clay, or kohwoso , and animal fat. The hojo is used for painting the faces of girls being initiated into the Sande, or Bundu, societies. This mixing palette is oval in shape, with decoration around the circumference. It appears not to have been used. It was acquired by Thomas J Alldridge in 1891.
A steatite, or soapstone, carinated circular disc, with a hole bored through the middle. Stones such as this are proliferate in Sierra Leone, and thought to be digging weights.

Kissi (or kisi) penny is a term given to a form of indigenous African currency, used in the interior of Sierra Leone in the 19th century. A Kissi penny consists of a rough strip or rod of iron, about a foot in length, which is t-shaped at one end, and flattened at the other.
One of three bill hooks made out of local iron, with wooden handles. Bill hooks are commonly used for cutting small woody vegetation, such as shrubs and branches.
One of three bill hooks made out of local iron, with wooden handles. Bill hooks are commonly used for cutting small woody vegetation, such as shrubs and branches.
One of three bill hooks made out of local iron, with wooden handles. Bill hooks are commonly used for cutting small woody vegetation, such as shrubs and branches.

A pair of saraka blacksmiths tongs. The tongs consist of two scissor-like blades working on a copper bolt. One of the handles has twisted fluting, the other has a small band of incised lines at the junction of the blade and the handle. The term saraka comes from the Arabic word for sacrifice but it was used widely in Sierra Leone to refer to objects imbued by ritual with spiritual power. These tongs are associated with blacksmiths, who were widely credited with spiritual powers in many parts of West Africa, which might explain the use of saraka in Alldridge s object description.

This dagger, or knife, has a wooden handle, decorated with tin. The dagger is encased in an ornate Mandingo leatherwork sheath, with a leather tassel at one end. Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone. Alldridge notes is came from Bafodia, lying north-west of Kabala.

This dagger has a Mori , or Mandingo, leather sheath, and plaited carrying handle. The carrying handle is composed of seven leather plaits, attached to the sheath with leather encased buttons. Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone.

A Mori , or Mandingo , leather bag. The mouth of the bag has a rim of reddish leather, the same leather encases the lower part of the bag. There is a hole on one side, which has been repaired with leather. The belt is a double plaited leather cord attached to the bag with a button. Mori or Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone.

A Mori , or Mandingo , leather bag. The bag is made from white and reddish brown leather; the base of the bag is decorated with impressed lozenges and lines. A belt of twelve plaited leather strings is attached to each end of the bag, and was used as a strap for carrying. Mori or Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone.

A leather bag and belt from Konnodogu , likely Koinadugu, in the north-east. The bag has flaps on both the back and the front that are decorated with a tooled line design. Three leather tassels are attached to the base, two of which have leather and cloth buttons. Two more leather tassels are attached as side pendants. A belt of seven leather plated strings passes through leather loops on the bag so that is can be easily worn. Alldridge compared is to a Sporran , a purse that is part of traditional Highland dress.

A sword and Mori leatherwork sheath. The sheath is decorated with horizontal and perpendicular impressed bands and two embossed buttons on the front. Two tassels are attached to the sheath, each with three plaited leather beads, along with a belt of nine plaited leather strings. Mori or Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone.
A goat skin bag with a leather loop at the top and near the bottom. These loops join with a looped belt of four smaller plaited leather strings for carrying.
Woven grass bag with diamond shape pattern. It has a plaited band forming a handle and a narrow ornamented band around the mouth. The bag is fastened with a button.

A long woven yellow grass bag. It is roughly cylindrical, with bands of red lines running from the top to bottom. The fibres are drawn into ten plaits at the mouth which are tied, in pairs, to a connecting string loop.
A woven yellow grass bag, undecorated. The fibres are gathered into six plaits at the mouth.

A dish cover, or luffah , to keep flies off of food, made from grass fibre woven into a bowl shape. The basket work is circular and shallow concave, woven in yellow, black and red fibre. This type of coil weave is associated with Temne basketry, though more commonly with the shuku blai container.

A dish cover, or luffah , to keep flies off of food, made from grass fibre woven into a bowl shape. The basket work is circular and shallow concave, woven in yellow, black and red fibre. This type of coil weave is associated with Temne basketry, though more commonly with the shuku blai container.

A dish cover, or luffah , to keep flies off of food, made from grass fibre woven into a bowl shape. The basket work is circular and shallow concave, woven in yellow, black and red fibre. This type of coil weave is associated with Temne basketry, though more commonly with the shuku blai container.

The bigger of two bowl shaped baskets, woven from grass and bass fibre. They both have a carinated body and a circular, concave cover. This basket is made from coiled basketry, using red, black, and yellow fibre to produce alternating vertical stripes.

The smaller of two bowl shaped baskets, woven from grass and bass fibre. They both have a carinated body and a circular, concave cover. This basket is made from coiled basketry, using red, black, and yellow fibre to produce alternating vertical stripes.
A woven grass, or raffia, cone-shaped bag. The mouth of the bag is fringed by ten long tassels which hang down the outside of the bag when worn. The bottom has been gathered, ending in a tuft.
A woven grass fibre fishing net from Mendiland . It is conical in shape.

A Mandingo men s square shaped robe in cream fabric with a simple embroidered design around the neck. This is a very early example of the kind of embroidered gown worn by Muslim elites (hence Mandingo ) in the north of Sierra Leone. It resembles an example from 1832 in the Ulster Museum, donated by Dr Henry McCormack.

A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example uses red, black, and yellow fibre to produce a pattern of alternating vertical stripes.

A glass bottle, encased in leatherwork, animal skin and woven fibre. The animal skin covers the central section and has its fur intact. The covered bottle resembles other examples from Kabala, encased in so-called Mandingo leatherwork.
CulturalObject.Materials: Glass; Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This one is typically boat-shaped. It was donated by Dr May Thorne, wife of Capt. Thorne, who was in Sierra Leone in 1910.

Cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example is composed or four strips in blue, brown and white. Sewn together, they create a chequered and herringbone pattern. The cloth is slightly fringed at the ends.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Captain J C Page (Collector), Mrs J E Page (Donor)

CulturalObject.Description: Two ivory bangles, decorated with incised and pierced designs.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Captain J C Page (Collector), Mrs J E Page (Donor)

CulturalObject.Description: A coil weave basket, commonly known as shuku blai . Shuku blai is a Temne name for a type of finely made and ornamented coil-weave basket, often made by women and used for keeping valuable objects safe. This example is made from black and yellow fibre, with red fibre on the cover rim.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Captain J C Page (Collector), Mrs J E Page (Donor)

CulturalObject.Description: A woven fibre bag. This example has a long carrying handle and a tassel at the base.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Captain J C Page (Collector), Mrs J E Page (Donor)

CulturalObject.Description: Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This one is typically boat shaped, and sits on a square stand.

A wooden carving depicting a male figure. The figure has a ridged hair style and an elongated segmented neck with 8 creases. It is fixed to a block of wood by metal straps over its feet. The figure wears a bead apron round its waist, decorated with black, orange, and green, string ties. Alldridge does not mention male figures in The Sherbro and its Hinterland. However, this figure may be part of a pair of male and female figures used by the Mende Njayei/Yassi society.

An unusual grass bag, designed to shield its contents in wet weather. It is an openwork netted bag, protected by lengths of grass, forming a fringed covering. A second fringed covering has been attached to the handle, which can be pulled up over the plaited domed top, acting as a second layer of fringing. Alldridge called this sort of bag a Portmanteau .
CulturalObject.Dimensions: Fragment 1: 490mm x 200mm x 110mm; Fragment 2: 430mm x 260mm x 90mm

CulturalObject.Description: A finely woven Mandingo scarf made from black palm fibre. It has an open netted diamond pattern with a long fringe. The Brighton Museum and Art Gallery catalogue says that is it from Galinas country, which lies in south-eastern Sierra Leone on the Liberian border.
A brown plaited and knotted fibre hammock. The Brighton Museum catalogue notes that it comes from the Mendiland .

A cylindrical bag made from leopard skin. The bag has a round base, and is fastened by a leather collar which slides down over the neck. The bag is worn using a double plaited loop which is fastened to the top using a button.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Thomas Joshua Alldridge (Collector); Arthur Foster Griffith (Donor)

CulturalObject.Description: One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals. They have layered leather soles, with a wide strap and a large domed bottom in red, yellow, and black, leather. Mandingo is a term used in the 19th century to refer to Muslim elites in the north of Sierra Leone.

One of a pair of Mandingo leather sandals. They have layered leather soles, with a wide strap and a large domed bottom in red, yellow, and black, leather. Mandingo is a term used in the 19th century to refer to Muslim elites in the north of Sierra Leone.
Two rattles made out of leather and grass fibre.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Vegetable, organic fibre

CulturalObject.Description: A gourd container for carrying milk or water. It has a large dark brown pear shaped body with a bulbous neck and a grass sting handle.
CulturalObject.Dimensions: Whole: 555 mm x 190 mm x 215 mm

CulturalObject.Description: This is a double ended drum with a carved design on the body, and animal skins stretched over each end. It is decorated with a pattern resembling leopard skin. The drum rattles when it is shaken.
A powder horn, encased in Mandingo leatherwork. Mandingo leatherwork is traditionally associated with Muslim elites and comes from the Northern Province of Sierra Leone.
CulturalObject.Materials: Leather, animal skin; Metal; Bone, ivory, tooth

CulturalObject.Description: A Xylophone-like musical instrument, called a Balangi, consisting of a series of wooden tone bars or keys attached to a wooden frame with small gourd resonators underneath, played with two beaters. It is particularly associated with the Kuranko, and other ethno-linguistic groups of Mande origin, in northern Sierra Leone. This one has 15 wooden rungs and 15 gourd fruits underneath. It was obtained from Chief Alimamy Bombo Lahai, the king of Tonkolambah , in 1909. Tonkolambah may refer to a Tonko Limba Chiefdom in Port Loko. For more information see T.J. Alldridge, The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page 289.
This is an adze, or hoe. It was most probably used for breaking up the earth in preparation for planting.

This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has been stained grey. This example resembles a set of figures photographed in T.J. Alldridge, The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, and which are now in the British Museum. They may have been carved by the same carver.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Arthur Foster Griffith (Donor); Thomas Joshua Alldridge (Possible collector)

CulturalObject.Description: This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has been stained grey. This example resembles a set of figures photographed in T.J. Alldridge, The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, and which are now in the British Museum. They may have been carved by the same carver.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Arthur Foster Griffith (Donor); Thomas Joshua Alldridge (Possible collector)

CulturalObject.Description: This is thought to be a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has been stained grey.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Arthur Foster Griffith (Donor); Thomas Joshua Alldridge (Collector)

CulturalObject.Description: Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has six converging rows of close plaits.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example is similar to a type identified as Gola; there are a number of similar masks in other museum collections, possibly made by the same carver.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has an elaborate hairstyle, fringed by a row of small sebe/sebbeh, or amulets, and surmounted by a large pyramidal object, potentially also representing an amulet. It is complete with black dyed raffia, hiding the body of the wearer.

Cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example is composed of eight strips of alternating blue and reddish-brown oblongs, edged with red and white. Sewn together, the strips create a chequered effect.

Cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example consists of thirteen strips with alternating blue and white oblongs, creating a striped effect at the top and bottom, and a chequered middle section. The edges are slightly fringed. This is one of the earliest examples of country cloth in the Brighton Museum and Art Gallery collections from Sierra Leone.

Cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example has sixteen blue strips, creating a striped effect. This is one of the earliest examples of country cloth in the Brighton Museum and Art Gallery collections from Sierra Leone.

Cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example has eighteen narrow brown strips; sewn together they create a chequered effect. This is one of the earliest examples of country cloth in the Brighton Museum and Art Gallery collections from Sierra Leone.

Cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example is unusual as it is composed of raised, tufted, pile in blue and white. It is also fringed with six tassels. The raised pile might suggest is was used for a hammock, making it either more comfortable, or more hard wearing.

Cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example is composed of sixteen strips in red, blue and white. Sewn together, they create a chequered pattern. The edges are slightly fringed. This is one of the earliest examples of country cloth in the Brighton Museum and Art Gallery collections from Sierra Leone.

Cloth, traditionally made from locally grown cotton that is spun into thread, dyed, and woven into strips on a tripod loom. The strips are then sewn together edge to edge to form the finished piece. Such cloth was, in the past, regarded as a sign of wealth and prestige. This example is composed strips in blue and white. Sewn together, they create a chequered pattern. This is one of the earliest examples in the Brighton Museum and Art Gallery collections from Sierra Leone.

A wooden carving depicting a female human head with an elongated, segmented, neck. It has been dyed black. The head has an elaborate hairstyle consisting of three erect lobes, similar to those found on many Mende female carvings. The original catalogue entry describes the carving as a mask , however it is unlikely to have been used in this way.
A wooden loom with cane and half-woven yarn.

A possible gonde Mask, painted white. The Gonde is an entertainment masker that appears together with the dignified ndoli jowei, or dancing Sowei, of the Sande society. It offers a parody of the latter by its own dishevelled appearance and undignified behaviour. The mask is often an old Sowei mask that is too decayed or damaged to be used for its original purpose. Unlike the ndoli jowei, little attempt is made to conceal the person wearing the mask.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has holes drilled for the suspension of raffia.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has metal earrings in its ears.
Carved wooden female figure standing on a stool. She appears to be wearing beadwork around her waist.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has finely plaited hair in three panels running across the head. It is surmounted by a triangular object and two horns, possibly representing sebe/sebbeh, or amulets.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood.
This resembles a Sowei Mask, though is too narrow to be worn. The Brighton Museum and Art Gallery catalogue suggests it was used on altars of the Sande society.

Carved wooden helmet mask used by the exclusively female Sande (Mende) or Bondo/Bundu (Temne) societies. The mask is traditionally worn by a high-ranking member of the society, the dancing sowei , known as the ndoli jowei among the Mende or a-Nowo among the Temne. Worn with a raffia costume, the masks typically have a polished black finish, with neck rings, elaborate coiffure and dignified facial expression. The mask is thought to represent conceptions of idealised womanhood. This example has three hair ridges, and three groups of four horns, possibly representing sebe/sebbeh, or amulets.

A large gongoli, or kongoli, mask, depicting the face of a human or animal, with red spots. The mask has a typical protruding forehead, top lip and vertical ears. The gongoli masquerader comes out to provide light entertainment, particularly during more solemn occasions such as funerals. It is not particular to any cultural groups in Sierra Leone.

The Brighton Museum and Art Gallery catalogue describes this as a minsereh , or min , figure, though the term has broadly been used to refer to any carved female wooden figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society rather than the carver. This example has an elaborate hairstyle
A finely woven cotton bag, composed of red and yellow cotton bands, with a plain cotton tassel at the base. The handle is formed of ten cotton strings with top and side tassels.

A Malian tilbi gown made from unbleached English calico with a crotchet design. The shoulders, front, and back panels have been embroidered in geometric designs outlined with light blue openwork embroidery. There is a large pocket over the chest. Tilbi gowns of this sort were worn by elites in the Niger trading towns of Djenne and Timbuktu, in what is now Mali. This one, collected by Alldridge, is of the earliest documented examples found in Sierra Leone.

A small netted basket, fringed to protect its contents from the rain. The top of the basket loop runs through the middle of a dense fringe of red and yellow, designed to let the water run off the bag, rather than soak its contents. Alldridge called this type of bag a Portmanteau .
A leather whip consisting of four plaited sennet thongs, attached to a cylindrical handle. The handle is decorated with black and yellow bands of natural fibre.
A leather whip consisting of four plaited sennet thongs, attached to a cylindrical handle. The handle is decorated with black and yellow bands of natural fibre.
Two leather whips consisting of thickly plaited sennet thongs, attached to a cylindrical handle. The handles are bound in coloured bands of grass string.
A woven grass bag with an all-over pattern of oblongs filled with alternating black and yellow lines. It has a seam at the bottom, and the mouth is gathered into 16 plaits.

A woven grass bag with an all-over pattern of oblongs filled with alternating black and yellow lines. It has a diagonal band of smaller patterned black dots between the yellow lines and a seam at the bottom. The mouth is gathered into 16 plaits, forming a handle.
A round black skull cap made out of plaited palm fibre and decorated with coils, circles of plaited fibre, and a tufted crest. It may have been used as wig, worn by dancers and public performers.

A plaited headdress made from six coloured circlets of plaited grass, or fibre string, with knots at regular intervals. Alldridge noted that it was worn by Mende women in mourning. More information can be found in The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page 119.

A plaited headdress made from light brown circlets of plaited grass, or fibre string, with knots at regular intervals. Alldridge noted that it was worn by Mende women in mourning. More information can be found in The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page 119.

A plaited headdress made from brown circlets of plaited grass, or fibre string, with knots at regular intervals. Alldridge noted that it was worn by Mende women in mourning. More information can be found in The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page 119.

A plaited headdress made from yellow circlets of plaited grass, or fibre string, with knots at regular intervals. Alldridge noted that it was worn by Mende women in mourning. More information can be found in The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page 119.

A plaited headdress made from twisted yellow and black circlets of plaited grass, or fibre string, with knots at regular intervals. Alldridge noted that it was worn by Mende women in mourning. More information can be found in The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page 119.

A plaited headdress made from black circlets of plaited grass, or fibre string, with knots at regular intervals. Alldridge noted that it was worn by Mende women in mourning. More information can be found in The Sherbro and its Hinterland, 1901, page 119.
Two necklaces made from many strings of small black vine beads and bunches of long red beads. Alldridge notes that they were worn by girls in Yandahu, Vassa.

Warri is a board game, variants of which are played all over Africa. The Sierra Leone version consists of a carved wooden board in which two rows of six cups are set alongside one another, with two larger receptacles at either end. It is played by distributing counters anti-clockwise. This one is roughly boat shaped, with each end flanked by a human head with an elongated, segmented, neck.
A wooden school board with a handle and slot for hanging. It is inscribed with Arabic texts and was likely used by school children learning the Q uran.
A container for snuff (sniffing tobacco), made out of a large piece of bamboo. Attached to the container are an iron rod, and an iron spatula.

A horn snuff container, complete with four iron spoons incised with patterns, an iron pick and an iron wire pendant. It was formerly the property of the late Chief Kailundu, or Kai Londo. Kai Londo was a famous warrior and chief of Luawa; an extensive territory on what became Sierra Leone s eastern border with Liberia. Kailahun was named after him, translated as Kai s town .
Small knife in sheath, decorated with ornate embossed metal.

A small bottle made out of elephant pad, and covered in unknown animal skin. The neck of the bottle is a reddish brown; the base flares out and is patterned with alternating white and black rings. It was used by Mende women as a cosmetics bottle, containing a powder used for colouring lower eyelids.

A small bottle made out of elephant pad, and covered in unknown animal skin. The neck of the bottle is a reddish brown; the base flares out into a rounded base and is patterned with alternating white and brown rings. It was used by Mende women as a cosmetics bottle, containing a powder used for colouring lower eyelids.
Two necklaces made of stings of small yellow grass beads.

CulturalObject.ObjectType: Costume, dress; Religious/ritual equipment, charms; Musical instruments
CulturalObject.Description: One of two rattles that were originally described as charms by Alldridge, but are actually leg or arm rattles worn by dances and other public performers. They are made from a flat oval piece of iron that is bent over to form a rattle. There is a loop at each end, with two additional loops attached to it that rattle when the wearer moves.

One of two rattles that were originally described as charms by Alldridge, but are actually leg or arm rattles worn by dances and other public performers. They are made from a flat oval piece of iron that is bent over to form a rattle. There is a loop at each end, with two additional loops attached to it that rattle when the wearer moves.

A heavy cotton gown made from country cloth. It has a black and blue striped design on a white background. It is rectangular in shape and has holes for the head and arms. This piece comes from a group of items purchased by the Brighton Museum from Alldridge in 1932. It is one of the earliest examples in the museum.
A wooden spool, complete with a soapstone, or steatite, whorl. The spindle has a spool of un-dyed cotton thread wound onto it. It was bought by Alldridge at Vande Road Market in Vassa, February 1891.

A large hook, made of two lengths of cylindrical iron rod that are joined at base with a wooden handle. They have been twisted together, and form two separate hooked points at the end. Alldridge notes the hook was used for dragging cavalry from their horses - it may have been used against Guinean Samori s Cavalry in the late 19th century.

A double bladed knife with a wooden handle. The blades are bill hooked, facing away from each other. Alldridge provides no comment on the significance of the double blade, though this example resembles knives carried by Gbendekolo funeral dancers among the Limba and Kuranko.
A knife, made out of an arrowhead shaped iron blade and a wooden handle. The blade originally had two barbs, but one was damaged.
An unusual curved sword with a leather sheath. The sword blade has an unsharpened pointed tip; the sheath is made of embossed leather and a flattened, leaf-shaped, end.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of Mende women playing a gourd rattle, or segure/segbureh. Other people are seen around them. The card is signed: T.J. Alldridge F.R.C.S. , and captioned Mendi women playing the “Sehgura”, the national musical instrument used by women throughout the Mendi Country, West Africa . Published as Figure 37 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Same as BMAG:WA900254.

Black and white photographic print showing two young girls standing outside a house. They are seen wearing a typical hairstyle from the late 19th century. The caption reads Photograph showing the Kolona - a head ornament, made from the Konk shell, worn by the Mandingo women upon tufts of their hair . The Kuranko name for the snail-shell toggle is inwora. Published as Figure 76 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). The caption reads: Native hairdressing - women of Mosaia wearing the Kolona. Warra-Warra, Limba Country.

Black and white photographic print showing a young man wearing a traditional robe and holding two short spears, standing outside a house. It is signed: T.J. Alldridge F.R.C.S. . The caption reads A young chief with two native spears made of country iron. Upper Mendi. West Africa . Published as Figure 65 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing four young women, initiated into the Sande society, wearing traditional hair styles which bare resemblance to those depicted on many Sowei masks. One girl has her face painted, two other girls have scarification marks over their forehead and stomach. All the girls also bear similar body adornment, or jewellery, across the chest and round the neck. The card is signed: T.J. Alldridge F.R.C.S. . The caption reads A group of Bundu girls in Vassa Country, Upper Mendi, West Africa . Published as Figure 63 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). It was possibly taken in February 1891 at Yandahu. On 21 February 1891 Alldridge made a treaty with Fabanna, chief of Vassa Country.

Black and white photographic print showing three men wearing loincloths and holding bows, arrows and a sword, standing near a house. It is card mounted. It is signed: T.J. Alldridge F.R.C.S. . The caption reads: War boys with bows and arrows. Bombari Country, Upper Mendi, West Africa . Published as Figure 59 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Photographic print showing two men with portable xylophones, or Balangi, strapped around their necks. They are seen within an area enclosed by a low fence. It is card mounted and signed: T.J. Alldridge F.R.C.S. , with the caption: Belanjeh Players. The Belanjeh is one of the principal instruments of the Mandingo, Mahommedan, people. West Africa .

Black and white photographic print showing three young women, probably initiated into the Sande society, wearing a rattle, or bunjue, on their backs while dancing. They wear pieces of imported printed cloth as skirtcloths, or lappa. It is card mounted and signed: T.J. Alldridge F.R.C.S. , with the caption: Upper Mendi women wearing the Bunjue – a musical accompaniment, suspended from the waist, while dancing . Published as Figure 67 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge notes that the photograph was taken in a place he records as Befuin, where he was treated to a country dance the like of which [he] had never seen .

Black and white photographic print showing a man wearing a traditional gown and cap. He is seen against a forest background. It is card mounted and signed: T.J. Alldridge F.R.C.S. with the caption: ‘The late chief Kai Lundu, of Luawa Country, Upper Mendi, West Africa.’ Kai Londo, who died in 1895, was a famous warrior and the chief of Luawa, an extensive territory on what became Sierra Leone’s eastern border with Liberia. The town of Kailahun (‘Kai’s town’) is named after him. Published as Figure 60 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Thomas Joshua Alldridge (Photographer); Kai Londo [Kai Lundu] (Subject)

CulturalObject.Description: Black and white photographic print showing an old man sitting on a slatted seat and surrounded by three women with bleached skirtcloths, or lappa s. The man is wearing a gown and cap and a large number of elephant pad bangles. In the background are some trees and a few houses of a village. It is card mounted and signed: T.J. Alldridge F.R.C.S. . with the caption: This photograph shows how the elephant pad bangles are worn by the chiefs and warriors in Upper Mendi, West Africa . Published as Figure 56 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing a group of men, women and children. They are seen posing within the area of a village. Written in pencil on the back of the image is 1 / Queen Messe of Massa, a chieftainess, surrounded by sub chiefs and people / Alldridge Neg List No 1 .

Black and white photographic print showing a thatched house, covered in white spots. Written in pencil on the back of the image is 2. Natives at Gippi town on Sherbro Island showing use of mats in house building where mud is unobtainable .

Black and white photographic print showing four young girls wearing headdresses and waist beads. Two of the girls are have scarification marks on their stomachs. Written in pencil on the back of the photograph is Fig. 44, p. 137 / Bundu [Sande] girls wearing fetish medicine, Upper Mendi / Alldridge Neg List No 3 . Published as Figure 44 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge describes the girls in the photograph as being the daughters of big chiefs, and notes that they are wearing a leopard s tooth, which is a sign of their having been free born, that is, not in slavery (p.137). He also writes that the loin cloths they are wearing are called Tutunias (ibid.).

Black and white photographic print showing five young girls wearing a cloth, or lappa, around their waist and with their arms uplifted. Their whole bodies have been painted in white clay. The scene is taking place within a village. Written on the back of the image is 5 / Fig. 43, p.136 / Bundu [Sande] girls (whitened) / Alldridge Neg List No 5 . Published as Figure 43 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge notes that By way of salute [the Bundu girls] raised their arms above their heads, then all together uttered a weird sound, which once heard can never be forgotten. It is one long-drawn note, which presently grows louder and then gradually dies away; while uttering this note they bend forward until their hands touch the ground, when they slowly rise to their original position (p.136).

Black and white photographic print showing four Tasso men with elaborate headdresses containing human skulls and thigh bones. Written in pencil on the back of the image is 6 / Fig. 41, p.134 / The Poro Secret Society - Group of Tasso men - Imperri Country / Alldridge Neg List No 6 . Published as Figure 41 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge writes: Next in power to the chiefs in the great Poro institution come the heads of the Poro, called the Tassos. Each big chief of a town has his own Tasso man, who, upon very important occasions, attends with his chief. When I photographed the four Tassos, it was at the conclusion of a very great and unusual meeting, the installation of a chief, after several years of interregnum. ... The four Tassos formed part of the chief s bodyguard, and took a prominent part in the ceremony. It is necessary to observe carefully the costumes worn by these men, particularly their enormous head-gear, which is about three feet in height. It is a great weight, and is consequently removed whenever the men are not actively engaged. These head-pieces are erected on a foundation of plaited cane. The human skulls and the thigh-bones immediately above the part fitting the head are those of defunct Tassos, which can only be renewed from other departed members of the order. The whole is surmounted by a gigantic bouquet of feathers, gathered from all kinds of birds, these bouquets being quite three feet in diameter. The dress of these men is of the usual barbaric description, made up of a network over the body, from which hang various skins of animals, bunches of fibre from the waist forming a short skirt; while attached to the knees are several pieces of hollowed native iron, from which depend rings of similar metal, that jingle as the men move about, making a considerable noise (pp.131-32).

Black and white photographic print showing a large group of people including a westerner, and four Tasso men, posing in an open area of a village. Written in pencil on the back of the image is 8. Fig. 40, p.132 / Installation of the Sokong of Imperri, showing Tasso men, and the Laka with his shield, to right of picture / Alldridge negative list No. 8 . Published as Figure 40 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). See Alldride s notes about the Tasso men associated with BMAG:WA900252. Of the Laka , Alldridge writes: The Tassos do not dance, that part of the [installation] ceremony being undertaken by the Laka and his followers, who are subordinate to the Tassos. It is only necessary for one Laka to be present in attendance upon several Tassos. The Laka in this instance will be noticed standing to the right, shield in hand, having his black body bedaubed with large white spots. Grouped at the back of him are his boys, to the number of about fifty, who are ready to rush madly round the town, headed by the Laka, to notify the people what is about to take place, call them together, or warn them to get into their houses (p.132).

Black and white photographic print showing a group of Mende women playing a gourd rattle, or segure/segbureh. Other people are seen around them. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 37, p.122 / Playing the Sehgura - the national musical instrument of the Mendi women / Alldridge Neg List No 9 . Published as Figure 37 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Same as BMAG:WA900182.

Black and white photographic print showing an old man sitting on a slatted seat and surrounded by three women with bleached cloths, or lappa s, wrapped around their waist. The man is wearing a traditional gown and cap and a large number of elephant pad bangles. Written in pencil on the back of the is Fig. 56, p.173 / Upper Mendi Chief wearing elephant pad bangles / Alldridge Neg List No 10 . Published as Figure 56 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Same as BMAG:WA900247.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of Mende women wearing different printed cloths, or lappa s, and with different hairstyles. These hairstyles resemble those found on many Sowei masks. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 34, p.113 / Showing some of the numerous styles in which the Upper Mende women dress their hair / Alldridge Neg list No 11 . Published as Figure 34 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Compare the hairstyles with the designs carved into many Sowei masks.

Black and white photographic print showing six young girls initiated into the Sande society. They are wearing head ties and bead-girdles around their waists, whilst standing near the front of a house. Also standing by are a man and a woman. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Six Vassa-Bundu girls wearing fetish medicines / Alldridge Neg List No. 12 .

Black and white photographic print showing a man wearing a boubou-style gown and a hat. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 60, p.190 / The late chief Kai Lundu, Luawa, Upper Mende / No.16 / Alldridge Neg List No 16 . Kai Lundu was a famous warrior and the chief of Luawa, an extensive territory on what became Sierra Leone’s eastern border with Liberia. The town of Kailahun (‘Kai’s town’) is named after him. He died in 1895. Published as Figure 60 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Same as BMAG:WA900246.
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Thomas Joshua Alldridge (Photographer); Kai Londo [Kai Lundu] (Subject)

CulturalObject.Description: Black and white photographic print showing a woman wearing a printed skirtcloth, or lappa, standing near a house. She is wearing a necklace made out of leopard s teeth, and large arm cuffs on each wrist. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 39, p.126 / Serenading - a Sophist - Upper Mendi / No. 17 / Upper Mendi Princess wearing leopard s teeth necklace. Sign of being free-born / Alldridge Neg List No 17 . Published as Figure 39 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing four men sitting on logs in a forest watched by two African policemen. Written in pencil on the back of the image is 26 / Oil Palm Forest, Sherbro / Alldridge Neg List No 26 .

Black and white photographic print showing three young men beating small drums strapped around their necks. A crowd of people can be seen close behind them. Written in pencil on the back of photograph Fig. 33, p. 113 / Beating Tom-tom or Sang-boi, by Mendi boys, fig. 33 / Alldridge Neg List No 27 . Published as Figure 33 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing the open area of a village with two tall drums standing in the middle. A group of children is leaning against large stones close by. Some people are seen sitting on the low outside wall of their houses. Three houses are visible in the background. Written in pencil on the back of photograph is 29 / The town drums, Mosaia, Warra Warra, Limba Country / Alldridge Neg List No 29 .

Black and white photographic print showing a country cloth strip that has woven by a man who is standing by his loom. Written in pencil on back of photograph is Fig. 31, p. 99 / Weaving country cloth on a native loom, Upper Mendi / Alldridge Neg List No 30 . Published as Figure 31 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print of two carvings in the form of stylised female figures, potentially minsereh , or min figures. Min figures are traditionally used as part of the Yasi (Bullom) or Njayei (Mende) society for curing sickness. They contain spiritual power which is given to the figure by members of the society, rather than the carver. Written in pencil on the back of the image is 32 / Fig. 51, p. 148 / Minsereh fetish images used in connection with the Yassi medicine / Alldridge Neg List No 32 . Published as Figure 51 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). These figures were acquired by the British Museum and correspond to BM:Af.1901.722.4 and BM:Af.1901.722.6.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of people. Three women stand on the left wearing lappa s and with their faces painted with white spots - they are likely to be associated with the Yassi society. In the middle is a man with a log drum, or kele. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 46, p.138 / Three Kambehs of the Yassi Society / Alldridge Neg List No 33 . Published as Figure 46 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing the backs of three women, probably members of the Yassi society. They stand with their shoulders and upper backs painted with white spots, and wearing skirtcloths, or lappa s. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 49, p.145 / Back view of the three Kambehs of the Yassi society / Alldridge Neg List No 34 . Published as Figure 49 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing an area of forest and palm trees. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 28, p.96 / Clearing bush for cassava cultivation, the young oil palms being left to mature. Bendu, Sherbro / Alldridge Neg List No 35 . Published as Figure 28 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print depicting three sampa girls wearing bunjue. A bunjue is a musical instrument worn around the waists of dancing girls, or Sampa , initiated into the Sande (Mende) or Bundu (Temne) society. Written in pencil on the back of the image is 36 / The Bunjue , danced by women in Upper Mendi / Alldridge Neg hist No 36 . Published as Figure 67 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge notes that the photograph was taken in a place he records as Befuin, where he was treated to a country dance the like of which [he] had never seen . Same as BMAG:WA900245.

Black and white photographic print showing a group of women and children, all but one seated. In front of the group is a pile of palm nuts waiting to be processed into palm oil. Next to them are three cooking pots. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Native women expressing palm oil at a Fakai by boiling the palm nuts in three-legged iron cauldrons. Turner s Peninsula, Sherbro / No. 37 / Alldridge Neg List No 37 . Published as Figure 18 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Photographic print showing two men with portable xylophones, or Balangi, strapped around their necks. They are seen within an area enclosed by a low fence. Written in pencil on the back of the photograph 39 / Belanjeh Players, The Belanjeh is one of the principal instruments of the Mandingo people, West Africa / Alldridge Neg List No 39 . Same as BMAG:WA900244.

Black and white photographic print showing three women near the edge of a forest. Two are pounding rice with long sticks into high wooden mortars; the woman in the middle is holding a broad shallow basket, or rice fan. Written in pencil on back of photograph 50? / Fig. 27, p. 94 / Native women cleaning rice, Bonthe, Sherbro / Alldridge Neg List No 40 . Published as Figure 27 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print of a woman. She is wearing an elaborate hairstyle, a necklace with three leopard s teeth, a little bag with strap across the chest and a skirtcloth, or lappa. Written in pencil on the back of the image is 41 / An Upper Mendi woman wearing three leopard s teeth - the sign of being free born / Alldridge Neg List No 41 .

Black and white photographic print showing three men standing near a house wearing loincloths and holding bows, arrows and a sword. Written in pencil on the back of the photograph is Fig. 59, p. 184 / War boys, Upper Mendi / Alldridge Neg List No 42 . Published as Figure 59 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Same as BMAG900243.

Black and white photographic print showing five young men dressed with elaborate costumes and surrounded by a crowd of people. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 38, p.126 / Poro boys in dancing costume, Juru, Gaura Country, Upper Mende / Alldridge Neg List No 44 . Published as Figure 38 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing five girls with their faces painted in white clay and wearing elaborate costumes. They are likely to be recently initiated into the Sande society, and potentially sampa . Written in pencil on the back of the photograph is Fig. 45, p. 138 / Bundu [Sande] girls in dancing costume / Alldridge Neg List No 45 . Published as Figure 45 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing the backs of five girls wearing elaborate costumes. They are likely to be recently initiated into the Sande society, and potentially sampa . These are the backs of the girls in image WA900276. Written in pencil on the back of the image 46 / Bundu [Sande] girls in dancing costume / Alldridge Neg List No 46 . This image shows the backs of the girls photographed in BMAG:WA900276.

Black and white photographic print showing four young women, initiated into the Sande society, wearing traditional hair styles which bare resemblance to those depicted on many Sowei masks. One girl has her face painted, two other girls have scarification marks over their forehead and stomach. All the girls also bear similar body adornment, or jewellery, across the chest and round the neck. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 63, p.211 / Bundu [Sande] girls, Vassa Country . Published as Figure 63 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Same as BMAG:WA900242.

Black and white photographic print titled Colonial Cricket as Played on the Main Road at Bonthe, Sherbro, January 1899 . Written in pencil on the back of the image Fig. 10, p.44 / A game of cricket upon the high road under Mango trees, Bonthe, Sherbro . Published as Figure 10 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print of a riverbank; three dugout canoes lay on the beach. Written in pencil on back of photograph Fig. 62, p.211 / The Falls at Tordaro Salima (Moa) River . Published as Figure 62 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing a quiet corner of a small river with a number of dugout canoes resting on the water near the river edge. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 21, p.77 / Country dug-out canoes, Sherbro . Published as Figure 21 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing a ndolo jowei, or dancing sowei , surrounded by a crowd of women and a few children. The masked dancer wears a helmet mask, trousers and a dyed black raffia cape. Some houses are visible in the background. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 48, p. 142 / Bundu Devil with attendant Digbas . Published as Figure 48 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge writes: After leaving the Bundu bush [i.e. after initiation] the girl if she likes can attain distinction in the higher degrees of Bunduism, of which there are three grades: Digba, the lowest or first degree. Normeh, the Bundu devil or second degree, and Soweh, the head woman, third degree. The Bundu devil is in the second degree of the medicine. If the girl wishes she can simply become a Digba; she then has the great privilege of holding the mat before the devil at any function (pp.141-42).

Black and white photographic print showing a rope bridge across a river. Three westerners are standing nearby. Written in pencil on the back of the photograph is Fig. 73, p. 286 / A Yenketti bridge over the Sehli [Seli] River, Koinaduga . Published as Figure 73 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Sir Frederic Cardew, Governor of Sierra Leone between 1894 and 1900, is pictured in the foreground. Of the bridge Alldridge writes: It is constructed entirely of long, coarsely interwoven rattan canes, the sides being supported by extra long canes, depending from the high trees upon both sides of the river. The elevation at both ends is some 25 feet above the water, but drops in the centre to about 12 feet. It is hardly necessary to remark that the oscillation of this bridge and its elasticity were such as to entirely absorb one s undivided attention, while groping an exceedingly unsteady and fitful passage through this swinging and dangerous open-work structure (pp.286-87).
CulturalObject.AssociatedPeople: Thomas Joshua Alldridge (Photographer); Sir Frederic Cardew (Subject)

CulturalObject.Description: Black and white photographic print showing a group of men posing for the photo. In the centre is a man playing the Balangi. Behind him, an older man is dressed in finer clothing and wearing a turban. Written in pencil on the back of the image Fig. 77, p.298 / The chief of Kukuna - Alimami Bassi - surrounded by his people (Mohammedans). Tonko Limba Country . Published as Figure 77 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge writes: The chief of [Kukuna] was the Alimami Bassi, who is sitting in the middle of Figure 77, in a white gown. In front of him sits his yele man, or musician, with his balenjeh. ... In this picture will be seen several people wearing gree-gree charms hanging from their necks. ... It will be noticed that two of the men are carrying umbrellas. Umbrellas would appear to be one of the first imported articles necessary to a native, irrespective of tribe, as soon as he comes into contact with the civilising trading establishments (pp.298-99).

Black and white photographic print showing a two-log bridge over a little stream in the bush. Written in pencil on the back of the image A good log bridge over a quagmire, through very beautiful ferns and palms, Bendu, Sherbro, fig.7 . Published as Figure 7 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing two shelters in the forest. Written in pencil on back of photograph is Fig. 52, p. 155 / The twin houses, or Sabo medicine (p. 149) . Published as Figure 52 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge describes the twin houses in some depth on pp.149-52 of the book.

Black and white photographic print of a man wearing an elaborate headdress and holding a sword whilst sitting on a stool outside a thatched building. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 64, p.212 / Fabanna, paramount chief of the Vassa country . Published as Figure 64 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing a man climbing an oil palm, aided by a strap passing around his waist. Written in pencil on the back of the image Fig. 17, p.65 / Ascending an Oil Palm to cut down the cones. Turner s Peninsula, Sherbro . Published as Figure 17 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print showing a section of a village with a tall tree growing near by. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 23, p.82 / A silk cotton tree without foliage, but with a mass of silky pods. Turner s Peninsula, Sherbro . Published as Figure 23 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan).

Black and white photographic print of a man and a woman wearing loincloths and sitting on the ground. A rope around their necks ties them together, and a small child sits on the woman s legs. A second man wearing a robe sits on the ground next to them. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Fig. 70, p.208 / A slave dealer with slaves at Mongeri . Published as Figure 70 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge writes: Upon arriving at the town of Mongeri, before reaching Konno, we found awaiting us a slave-dealer who had just been captured upon the road by the police. The party consisted of the slave-dealer, a man, a woman and her child, as shown in Figure 70 (p.268). The slaves were set free by Alldridge, and he goes on to explain, The slave-dealer considered it very hard upon him that he should be deprived of what he held to be his legitimate purchases; for, as he stated, he had bought the people near by and was then taking them to the Susu country, a French possession a long way off, to exchange them for cattle. He said he had paid eight pieces of cloth for the man, eight pieces for the woman, and three pieces for the child, the value of a piece of such cloth being probably three shillings (ibid.).

Black and white photographic print showing a section of a village (Kase Town, Sherbro). A group of people is sitting against a house. Before them an area of the ground is marked off by a circle of bottles, surrounding a grave. Published opposite p.100 in T. J. Alldridge, 1910, A Transformed Colony (London: Seeley) with the caption: A grave surrounded by gin bottles: The ceremony after the death of any person of consequence is called pulling the cry, and is not unlike a wake. Much gin is drunk, and the empty bottles are inserted neck downwards in the earth around the grave. An empty demijohn which had contained rum, ornaments the hut on the left, and a broken gin bottle that on the right.

Black and white photographic print showing three young men with palm leaf hampers on their backs. Written in pencil on the back of the image is Natives carrying produce from the hinterland of Sherbro, in palm in leaf hampers . Published opposite the title page in T. J. Alldridge, 1910, A Transformed Colony (London: Seeley) with the caption: Palm-leaf hampers. These hampers are admirably adapted for overland transport along the narrow paths. Though so fragile looking they are extremely strong, and it is surprising how much can be packed into them.
A black and white photographic print of trees growing along the edge of a river or lake.
Black and white photographic print showing a young boy wearing an elaborate costume and headdress standing in an open area near some western-style buildings. He is wearing rattles around his ankles.

Black and white photographic print showing Alldridge as a member of the Frontier police, which was formed in 1890. He is surrounded my men, two of whom are supporting a hammock with a canopy behind him. Alldridge writes of the advantages of such a canopy being to allow shade whilst jotting down topographical observations and taking compass bearings.
Black and white photographic print showing a man standing in an open area in the forest.
Black and white photographic print showing a large group of men wearing traditional country cloth gowns.

Black and white photographic print showing a ndoli jowei , or dancing sowei. The masked dancer wears a helmet mask, trousers and a dyed black raffia cape. The mask type resembles masks of an early date, identified as Gola. The photograph is mounted on a card, with writing in pen on reverse of the mount reading March 1899 . Published as Figure 47 in T. J. Alldridge, 1901, The Sherbro and Its Hinterland (London: Macmillan). Alldridge writes of the Bundu devil : Her distinctive costume is unvarying, all Bundu devils being similarly attired, except as regards their head-piece, which admits of some slight variation. No part of the body may be visible, consequently the cloth casings of the arms and legs are sewn up at the extremities, and in each covered hand the devil carries a little bunch of twigs... Her dress is of a long shaggy fibre, dyed black, and over her head she wears a grotesque wooden mask (p.141).
